## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for November 23, 2022 - November 29, 2022
##
## Message Issue Date: 2022-11-30T21:08:11Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2022-11-23T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2022-11-29T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20221130-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were 9 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, the following CME impacts were estimated:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Location/Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2022-11-26T11:53Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2022-11-27T19:56Z (see notification 20221126-AL-001)
2022-11-27T17:38Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2022-11-28T22:30Z (see notification 20221127-AL-003)
2022-11-28T21:36Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2022-11-30T04:29Z (see notification 20221129-AL-001)

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5.33 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5.33 occurred during the synoptic period of 2022-11-28T03:00Z-06:00Z.  This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the detected arrival by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2022-11-27 with an associated interplanetary shock detected at 2022-11-27T17:03Z (see notification 20221128-AL-001). 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu starting at 2022-11-27T13:45Z. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream arrival detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2022-11-24. The solar wind reached a maximum sustained speeds of over 620 km/s on 2022-11-26 (see notifications 20221124-AL-001, 20221127-AL-001 and 20221127-AL-002). Later on, the electrons were elevated and crossed the threshold a second time starting at 2022-11-29T13:55Z.  This second increase may have been associated with the arrival of the coronal hole high speed stream around 2022-11-27 mentioned above.  The solar wind speed reached values of 700 km/s on 2022-11-29 and 2022-11-30 (see notifications 20221128-AL-001 and 20221129-AL-002).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2022-11-30T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2022-12-06T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to minor for the upcoming week. There is only one active region present on the Earth's facing disk. However, this active region has remained active producing B and C class flares through the reporting period and can remain active for the next several days.  There are two unumbered active regions seen in the STEREO A imagery that will be rotating to the Earth facing disk around 2022-12-01.

The geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming reporting period. There is a coronal hole currently located at N02W30 that will may become geoeffective around 2022-12-01.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2022-11-29T14:21:26Z
## Message ID: 20221129-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2022-11-29T13:55Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a coronal hole high speed stream that arrived at L1 on 2022-11-27 (see notification 20221128-AL-001), reaching a maximum sustained speed of approximately 700 km/s. The solar wind observed at L1 is currently around  600 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2022-11-29T13:55:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2022-11-28T21:36Z.

Estimated speed: ~525 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 40 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -75/-37 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2022-11-28T21:36:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Parker Solar Probe.  The leading edge of the CME will reach Parker Solar Probe at 2022-11-30T04:29Z (plus minus 7 hours).

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR at L1 at 2022-11-27T17:03Z. 

The magnetic field enhancement may be associated with a high speed stream from one of several small northern coronal holes on the Earth-facing disk. Some magnetospheric compression and a minor geomagnetic storm is expected.

Activity ID: 2022-11-27T17:03:00-IPS-001.

Activity ID: 2022-11-24T17:58:00-IPS-001.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for November 16, 2022 - November 22, 2022
##
## Message Issue Date: 2022-11-23T20:56:10Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2022-11-16T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2022-11-22T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20221123-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period with 1 M-class flare, 12 C-type CMEs, and 1 O-type CME (see details below).  

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that these CMEs may impact NASA missions near Earth: 

CME Starting time  | Predicted Arrival Time (plus minus 7 hours)   | Estimated Kp
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2022-11-19T09:48Z   Missions near Earth at about 2022-11-22T04:51Z   Maximum Kp index is 3-5 (below minor to minor)(see notification 20221119-AL-001)
2022-11-22T08:00Z   Missions near Earth at about 2022-11-25T11:57Z   Maximum Kp index is 3-4 (below minor to minor)(see notification 20221122-AL-001)

An ensemble was created for the CME first visible at 2022-11-19T09:48Z with 24 members. The CME was estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2022-11-21T18:30Z and 2022-11-22T05:42Z (average arrival 2022-11-22T01:20Z) for 58% of simulations. The full results can be found here: 
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2022-11-19_ncmes1_sims24_HILOX158/Detailed_results_20221119_094800_ncmes1_sims24_HILOX158.txt (see notification 20221120-AL-001). The arrival of this CME may have been detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2022-11-22T06:22Z by a weak signature in the solar wind parameters, and at STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC data around 2022-11-22T14:44Z.

An ensemble was created for the CME first visible at 2022-11-22T08:00Z with 48 members. This CME was also associated with a C7.0-class flare from AR 13151 that peaked at 2022-11-22T07:27Z. The CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2022-11-25T02:59Z and 2022-11-25T19:35Z (average arrival 2022-11-25T11:40Z) for 97% of simulations. The full results can be found here: 
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2022-11-22_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX159/Detailed_results_20221122_080000_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX159.txt (see notification 20221122-AL-003).

It was also estimated that the following CMEs were predicted to impact other locations/missions:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Location/Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2022-11-18T09:36Z   OSIRIS-REx at 2022-11-21T09:24Z (see notification 20221118-AL-001)
2022-11-19T09:48Z   STEREO B at 2022-11-22T06:14Z, Mars at 2022-11-23T18:00Z, Solar Orbiter at 2022-11-21T16:00Z, and STEREO A at 2022-11-22T10:00Z (see notifications 20221119-AL-001 and 20221120-AL-001)
2022-11-21T01:23Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2022-11-22T14:18Z (see notification 20221121-AL-001)
2022-11-22T08:00Z   Solar Orbiter at 2022-11-24T14:32Z, STEREO A at 2022-11-25T06:03Z, Mars at 2022-11-27T10:00Z, and STEREO B at 2022-11-25T18:00Z (see notifications 20221122-AL-001 and 20221122-AL-003). 
2022-11-22T13:48Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2022-11-24T04:34Z (see notification 20221122-AL-002)

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3.67 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=3.67 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2022-11-21T00:00Z-06:00Z.  This minor enhancement was associated with the arrival of the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2022-11-20 and associated interplanetary shock observed around 2022-11-20T13:48 (see notification 20221120-AL-002). 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2022-11-23T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2022-11-29T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming reporting period. There are four numbered active regions in the Earth's facing disk.  Active region 13151 just developed on the Earth facing disk around 2022-11-21 and it has been the most active in the last few days producing several C class flares, one of them associated with one of the CMEs mentioned above. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to minor for the upcoming week.  There are several small coronal holes that may become geoeffective in the next few days. The first one is located around N20W35 that can cause a slight enhancement in the Earth environment around 2022-11-24.  The second one is located currently close to the central meridian and may become geoeffective around 2022-11-28.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update (ensemble) (STEREO A, Mars, STEREO B, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2022-11-22T22:31:01Z
## Message ID: 20221122-AL-003
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2022-11-22T08:00:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20221122-AL-001). Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A, STEREO B, and Mars. For 48 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2022-11-24T23:05Z and 2022-11-25T10:59Z (average arrival 2022-11-25T05:41Z) for 85% of simulations.
- STEREO B between about 2022-11-25T05:29Z and 2022-11-25T23:06Z (average arrival 2022-11-25T14:47Z) for 97% of simulations.
- Mars between about 2022-11-26T21:59Z and 2022-11-27T13:26Z (average arrival 2022-11-27T07:47Z) for 62% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2022-11-25T02:59Z and 2022-11-25T19:35Z (average arrival 2022-11-25T11:40Z) for 97% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 96% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-5 range (below minor to minor).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2022-11-22_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX159/20221122_080000_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX159_anim_tim-den.gif

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2022-11-19T09:48:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20221119-AL-001). Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A, STEREO B, and Mars. For 24 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2022-11-22T01:29Z and 2022-11-22T12:47Z (average arrival 2022-11-22T07:08Z) for 8% of simulations.
- STEREO B between about 2022-11-21T21:29Z and 2022-11-22T07:59Z (average arrival 2022-11-22T04:05Z) for 66% of simulations.
- Mars between about 2022-11-23T10:57Z and 2022-11-23T17:43Z (average arrival 2022-11-23T13:52Z) for 12% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2022-11-21T18:30Z and 2022-11-22T05:42Z (average arrival 2022-11-22T01:20Z) for 58% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 95% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-5 range (below minor to minor).

## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during this reporting period with 4 M-class flares and 4 C-type CMEs (see list/details below). 

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the following CME was predicted to impact:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2022-11-14T03:24Z    Missions near Earth at 2022-11-17T12:11Z and STEREO B at 2022-11-17T13:01Z (see notification 20221114-AL-001)

An ensemble was also created for this CME with 48 members. The full results can be found here: 
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2022-11-14_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX157/Detailed_results_20221114_032400_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX157.txt (see notification 20221114-AL-002).

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2022-11-10T14:55Z (see notifications 20221110-AL-001 and 20221110-AL-002). This elevated electron flux may be associated with the arrival of CME with ID 2022-11-03T08:48:00-CME-001 and/or CME with ID 2022-11-04T07:48:00-CME-001 first detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2022-11-07.  The energetic electron flux subsided to background levels late on 2022-11-11 and remained at background levels for the remainder of the reporting period.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been minor to moderate this week due to the effects of the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels throughout the outlook period. There are currently 4 numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13141 (N14W77) has produced several M-class flares during the reporting period, but has remained quiet in the recent days. Active Region 13140 (N25W87) has been responsible for the majority of flares lately including a M1.0-class flare on 2022-11-15. These Active Regions may produce more flaring activity throughout the outlook period before rotating off the Earth-facing disk by approximately 2022-11-17. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be at minor to moderate levels throughout the outlook period.  There may be some minor enhancement in the geomagnetic activity due to the arrival of two S-type CMEs first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2022-11-13T11:36Z and 2022-11-14T03:24Z, respectively, which are predicted to impact missions near Earth around 2022-11-17. The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt is currently below the threshold level of 1000 pfu, but could be enhanced near the end of the outlook period due to the arrival of a large coronal hole currently centered near S35E25 that may reach geoeffective longitudes by 2022-11-20.

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2022-11-14T03:24:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20221114-AL-001). Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO B and Mars. For 48 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO B between about 2022-11-17T02:17Z and 2022-11-17T21:55Z (average arrival 2022-11-17T13:50Z) for 64% of simulations.
- Mars between about 2022-11-18T17:59Z and 2022-11-19T09:27Z (average arrival 2022-11-19T03:06Z) for 18% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2022-11-17T03:27Z and 2022-11-17T15:06Z (average arrival 2022-11-17T10:10Z) for 25% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 89% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-4 range (below minor to below minor).

Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

## Summary:

Solar activity varied between low and minor levels during this reporting period with 1 M-class flare and 4 C-type CMEs (see details/list below).      

Geomagnetic activity was at minor storm levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp = 5 occurred during the synoptic periods 2022-11-03T12:00Z-18:00Z and 2022-11-07T15:00Z-18:00Z. The first elevation in Kp observed on 2022-11-03 was likely associated with the arrival of the coronal hole high speed stream first detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2022-11-02 with an associated interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2022-11-02T11:45Z (see notification 20221103-AL-001). The maximum sustained solar wind speed observed by DSCOVR at L1 reached approximately 580 km/s. The second elevation in Kp observed on 2022-11-07 was possibly associated with the arrival of a S-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2022-11-03T08:48Z and/or the S-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO at 2022-11-04T07:48Z. This arrival was associated with the interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 at 2022-11-07T07:40Z (see notification 20221107-AL-003). This arrival is still under analysis. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt was enhanced at the beginning of this reporting period due to a threshold crossing during the previous reporting period beginning at 2022-10-29T17:10Z, caused by a coronal hole high speed stream which arrived on 2022-10-28 (see notifications 20221029-AL-001, 20221029-AL-002, 20221031-AL-001, and 20221102-AL-001). Energetic electron flux levels were further enhanced on 2022-11-03, crossing the threshold level of 1000 pfu again at 2022-11-03T12:35Z (see notifications 20221104-AL-001 and 20221106-AL-001). These elevated energetic electron flux levels were likely caused by the additional enhancement of a new coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2022-11-02. The energetic electron flux levels subsided to background levels late on 2022-11-07 and remained at background levels for the remainder of the reporting period.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been minor to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

The most notable of these, Active Region 13135 (N25E05), has been the source of B-class and low-level C-class flaring throughout the outlook period. An unnumbered Active Region is visible on the STEREO A eastern limb around latitude N25 and may be expected to rotate onto the Earth-facing disk on or around 2022-11-04.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels throughout the outlook period. The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt currently remains elevated around or above 1000 pfu, as a result of the lingering effects of the coronal hole high speed stream, and may remain elevated through the beginning of the outlook period (see notification 20221102-AL-001). A coronal hole centered around S05W15 may become geoeffective on or around 2022-11-03.
